info_card.title: KISS - Kunstbibliothek in Seestadt
info_card.subtitle: Interactive Tangible Design
info_card.desc: A Public Visual & Interactive Library to discover & support local Artists through physical yet digital artbooks.

project_overview.desc: KISS combines the traditional free little library with digital art exhibitions. Passersby can still pick up or drop off regular books, but they also have the chance to interact with special art books. These books act as canvases for projected artworks, offering a tangible yet immersive way to experience local creativity. Interaction is further enriched through a hand-sized dice that lets users explore more information about the artworks and artists, express their feelings, and even connect to merchandise opportunities that support local artists financially.
project_overview.objective: This project was conducted as part of a university course focused on Design Thinking. The course encouraged students to develop projects without restrictions on theme, technology, or impact, with the aim of animating and enriching public life in Seestadt (Vienna, Austria). Our team of four chose to support local artists, recognizing both the financial instability of the profession and its vital role in making communities more vibrant and livable. By showcasing art in Seestadt, we sought to bring soul and cultural identity to its newly built streets.
project_overview.skills: Design Thinking, User Research, Wireframing, Prototyping, Product Business Identity, Various Design Methods
project_overview.tech: Laser cutting machines for prototyping, painting and material finishing, SVG vector graphics, Canva for visual communication materials, graphic production for flyers and posters.

steps.content:
Our only initial instructions and starting point were that we eventually needed to include the following in our project: "sustainability, infrastructure, creativity and the neighborhood of Seestadt". The project also had to include technology and computers in some way (since it was part of a computer science curriculum) and also that interactions must be tangible. This of course gave us a lot of freedom to choose what we could do, but also made it seem like we would not be able to find a good enough theme or idea to start.

Design thinking is an infinite cycle between expanding the ideas we come up with, then focusing inward and delving deeper onto some of them, then once again expanding on the selected concepts by allowing ourselves more creative freedom before refocusing on a specific idea. I showcase this cycle with little converging/diverging icons on each step.

Here we were only at the beginning, so we did not restrain our imaginations in producing lots of ideas, many of which were not close to what we eventually did, but that perhaps could have influenced even in a small way our approach or our final design.

steps.step_title: Ideation: is this even a good idea? ⚞
steps.content:
Eventually, we closed in on creating something that could benefit artists. Stereotypically, we had the vision that artists are people doing this work for the love of art and not for money, and that being an artist as a job was poorly remunerated.

Of course, we quickly came across the need to actually check whether that cliché even held a semblance of truth, or at the very least, to what extent artists need to be financially supported, as well as investigating several ways to do that.

To do that, we each conducted literature research to find sources and arguments that could support (or disprove) our initial hypothesis that artists needed help financially, and how to provide that. On my side, I primarily focused on art economics and the art market as a whole. Through this research, we found several promising ways to support artists financially, such as through merchandising or, to a lesser extent nowadays, NFTs. We also found that entering the traditional art market is tedious and that only a minority of living artists really profit from it.

It then became clear to us that this target group and our objective was promising, so we decided to keep it.

steps.step_title: Ideation: well... what do we build now? ⚟
steps.content:
One could say that there are countless forms of art, and while that is a beautiful sentiment, we couldn't find an idea that we liked that encompassed all forms of art (while still respecting the few limitations we had). We circled around ideas of community workshops with tutorials projected onto canvases or material to help people hone their crafts, or around a way to "geocache" artworks around the city for a gamified way for people to discover local artists.

Eventually, we came up with an idea of an interactive digital street signage installation that would display art to everyone passing by. People stopping at our installations could vote or give their opinion on the art and eventually buy merchandise to support the artist. You could in a way describe it as public art doomscrolling.

picture.alt: Sketch of interactive digital street signage idea

steps.content:
Now that we had an idea, or at least a direction to focus on, we needed to refine it. We gathered more information by preparing and conducting several design methods:

  • First, we each conducted interviews with experts in different domains involved in our current idea. The goal was to identify potential challenges, gather intel about the feasibility of our concept, and evaluate it. For instance, I interviewed the CEO of a Slovakian Digital Signage company, from whom I learned several important difficulties behind public digital signage. With these interviews, we narrowed down our design by integrating the information we gathered.
  • Next, we prepared and handed out Cultural Probes to local inhabitants of Seestadt. This allowed us to present our idea to people who would be affected by it, gaining direct feedback, and to collect information about their behaviors, preferences, and habits regarding art, art rating, and Seestadt itself.
  • Lastly, we created a tabletop game mimicking the rating interactions we were considering. We hosted games with inhabitants of the neighborhood and observed their behaviors to understand how the rating system impacted their perception of the art.

Through these methods, we learned a lot about people's preferences, especially their habits in the neighborhood and their preferred way of rating art. All of this helped develop our concept idea into the final form of this purely ideational first phase of the project.

picture.alt: Cultural probes handed out to Seestadt inhabitants

steps.content:
We had a concrete, solid idea at the end of the ideation phase. However, we realized that our concept wasn't tangible enough, and the interactions lacked memorability. We went back to the drawing board, sketching interaction ideas while maintaining the core concept of a free little library with visual local art display and rating possibilities.

We developed the idea of 'special books' onto which local art would be projected. An additional tool or object could serve as a controller to enable further interactions. We considered pens (visually or magnetically tracked), ropes and pulleys, and finally decided on a hand-sized cube or dice to enable interactions.

picture.alt: Sketches of special books and interaction ideas

steps.content:
The interactions worked as follows:

  • Users first selected a special book (each book corresponding to different art collections). Placing it in the projection area allowed them to flip through the artworks. The books were otherwise blank, meaning they couldn't be used outside the system.
  • Users could rotate the control dice to select options for the current artwork projected onto the book. Each face of the cube enabled a different interaction, for a total of six options, such as revealing more information, rating the artwork, or expressing feelings along an emotions circle.

To refine the idea, we created a physical mock-up and a digital wireframe. Student testers highlighted issues like ergonomics (books needed to be readable and comfortable) and interaction clarity (special books and cubes are uncommon items). The tests also confirmed the concept's interestingness and that we were moving in the right direction.

picture.alt: Mockup and wireframe screenshots of the special books and cube interactions

steps.step_title: Prototyping: What would it look like? How do we make it work? ⚞
steps.content:
With the UX approach confirmed, we worked on both visual design (UI and business identity) and technical implementation. Using a mobile phone, projector, 3D-printed cube, and QR-code stickers, we developed a Kotlin app displaying different screens based on the QR codes on books or cubes. The phone projected these screens onto the books.

I handled business identity and visuals. We named the project “Kunstbibliothek in SeeStadt” (KISS), reflecting the product and location, and making a memorable acronym.

The logo uses the acronym KISS:

  • K: an open book, symbolizing both libraries and art experience.
  • I: a brush, representing art; a drop of paint flows into the first S.
  • SS: fluid letters symbolizing Seestadt lake and unrestrained art; identical letters ensure readability.

The logo has a blue gradient referencing Seestadt lake, introducing movement and evoking trust and confidence for collaborating artists.

picture.alt: Evolution of the KISS logo and 3D model concept

steps.content:
We built a high-fidelity prototype. No suitable shelf existed, so we made one ourselves. Using laser-cut wood for eco-friendliness and transportability, we customized premium notebooks as 'special books', each color-coded for differentiation. The interactive cube was 3D printed in blue and decorated with decal stickers for interaction symbols.

The shelf exterior was painted white with blue marks; the interior projection area was dark to improve projection quality. The phone and projector were hidden at the top. Additional promotional materials like posters and flyers were designed to attract participants.

picture.alt: Final prototype with shelf, books, and promotional poster

steps.content:
The final stage involved testing our prototype in Seestadt near a supermarket. We successfully attracted participants.

We used a Think-Aloud Protocol:

  • Introduce the system, its purpose, and interactions.
  • Participants interact with the system, verbalizing their thoughts.
  • Observers intervene only if the participant is stuck or misses a key feature.
  • After several minutes, participants are asked about their experience and opinions on KISS.
  • Notes and anonymous recordings were taken throughout.

picture.alt: Prototype being tested in Seestadt with participants

process.results:
In total, we conducted tests with 7 passerbys over a period of approximately an hour and a half. Overall feedback was very positive and highlighted how promising this idea is. Several participants enjoyed the interactions and expressed a desire for such a library to remain in their neighborhood. Most participants handled all interactions well once explained, and most also appreciated the idea of supporting artists, particularly local ones.

Areas for improvement include using a better, brighter projection device, creating a smaller interaction cube (especially relative to the size of the book), and including more art collections and diverse art genres (as well as actual human-made art, in contrast to the AI-generated art that was used). Additionally, we did not focus on designing and implementing the merchandising aspect of the system, and thus the financial support for artists. If we were to continue this project, the next step would involve applying Design Thinking to create the merchandising flow for users, and a system for artists to sell and submit their work for display.
process.personal_reflection:
I really enjoyed this project and learning about new design methods, especially through practical application. Conducting all of these methods helped me realize how important empathy is when designing for people, as it is the best way to understand what can and should be created. It also opened my eyes to the courage of people who approach strangers on the streets to raise awareness, ask questions, or promote a cause. Capturing people’s attention in this way is far harder than it seems. After this project, I spoke with more of them and gained even greater appreciation for their efforts.

Finally, as a UX designer and engineer, this project introduced me to the concept of iterative design, and I found myself enjoying it immensely. Of course, there are limitations to everything, and Design Thinking does not eliminate them. In particular, some people follow it strictly like a recipe, but I see it more as a toolbox of suggestions. Nevertheless, my approach to designing and managing projects through structured design phases has definitely evolved and been influenced by the principles of Design Thinking.

This project has fundamentally shaped how I approach UX and engineering: iterative, empathetic, and adaptable to real user needs.

info_card.title: Node Wars
info_card.subtitle: Multiplayer Unity-based Strategy Game
info_card.desc: A PC multiplayer turn-based strategy game set in space, where civilizations compete to dominate a galaxy of interconnected planets through tactical expansion.

project_overview.desc: Node Wars is a turn-based multiplayer strategy game for PC that takes place in space. The map is composed of interconnected circles representing planets, each divided into multiple segments. Players take on the role of rival civilizations, competing to conquer planets and strategically block opponents in a race for galactic domination.
project_overview.objective: This game was developed as part of a Game Design course. Throughout the course, we explored different game concepts by working with specific mechanic constraints (for example, creating a one-button game or a pattern-prediction game). These exercises helped us practice how to quickly generate and test game ideas. After this warm-up phase, me and another student were tasked with developing a final project: designing and implementing a complete game of our own using the technology of our choice. Node Wars emerged as the result of this process.
project_overview.skills: Game Design, Unity Development, Local Multiplayer, Systems Design, UI/UX for Games
project_overview.tech: Unity, C#, Git for version control, Inkscape for assets

steps.content:
The very first version of Node Wars was not space-themed at all. Instead, it started as a purely abstract strategy game where the focus was entirely on mechanics. The playing field was designed as a collection of interconnected circles, each divided into multiple sections. Players would take turns coloring these sections with their chosen color.

The core rule of the game was simple: a player could color a section only if the circle was unclaimed or if they already controlled at least one section of it. Once all sections of a circle were filled by the same player, the circle was considered conquered. At that moment, a key mechanic, propagation, would be triggered: the player’s color spread into all directly connected circles. This propagation not only added a new colored section to neutral circles, but also replaced any sections already controlled by opponents, creating sudden and dramatic shifts in control.

This mechanic encouraged players to think several steps ahead. Choosing the right circle to conquer could cause chain reactions that flipped entire regions of the board, while a poorly timed move could set up an opponent for a devastating blow. Even without a theme, this early prototype already demonstrated the potential for deep strategy arising from very simple rules.

At this stage, the game was entirely about testing, refining, and balancing these mechanics. The thematic layer, civilizations battling for galactic dominance, was added later, but the abstract strategy roots remain at the heart of Node Wars.

picture.alt: Early Sketches of our game mechanic.

steps.content:
Eventually, to make the game more compelling to play and to deepen the overall experience, we needed to add a cosmetic layer to it. A good way to achieve this was by choosing a theme for the game. A theme is one of the most obvious and visible aspects of a game, as it defines its visual identity and gives players a recognizable context to engage with.

In regard to the MDA (Mechanic-Dynamic-Aesthetic) framework, we already had the mechanics in place. Adding a theme to the game mostly impacts the aesthetic layer, rather than the core mechanics or dynamics. Therefore, many different topics could have worked with our core mechanic, especially given its network and graph-theory foundation, which lends itself to a wide range of domains.

The idea of space as a theme came naturally. When I was younger, I played Star Wars Battlefront 2 (2005) on the PS2, which included a Galactic Conquest mode. In that mode, the player faced an opponent for galactic domination on a node-based map of star systems, with battles fought to determine the winner. More recently, I had played community mods for Hearts of Iron 4 that recreated the Star Wars universe, allowing players to immerse themselves in familiar factions and stories. These experiences made the space theme feel like a natural fit, both visually and mechanically, for the game.

picture.alt: Screenshots of the galactic conquest game mode of Star Wars Battlefront 2 (2005) and of the Star Wars: PROJECT VALACHORD mod for Hearts of Iron 4

steps.content:
The core version of Node Wars was developed in less than a month. Once the basic mechanics were in place, we focused on small quality-of-life updates and bug fixes to make the experience more polished and stable.

After reaching a playable prototype, we organized testing sessions with other players to gather early feedback. The game quickly became one of the favorites among those presented, with testers praising its strategic aspect, and the excitement of the propagation mechanic. Players found the chain-reaction system particularly satisfying, as it created unexpected yet logical swings in control.

However, the tests also revealed key areas for improvement. Some first-time players struggled to understand how propagation worked without explicit guidance. In addition, the initial map layout appeared slightly unbalanced, with the first player sometimes having a noticeable advantage. These insights helped define our next steps: improving onboarding, balancing gameplay, and finding ways to add more strategic depth.

picture.alt: Screenshots of the first version of Node Wars during testing sessions

steps.content:
At this stage, the game revolved around a single objective, conquering the opponent and eliminating them from the board. While this worked well mechanically, it made the experience feel somewhat one-dimensional. Players had limited strategic options and tended to adopt similar approaches each match.

To address this, we introduced additional winning conditions designed to diversify gameplay and encourage players to think on multiple levels. The goal was to let players pursue different paths to victory and manage various aspects of the game simultaneously, leading to richer strategic decisions.

The final three victory conditions were:

  • Domination Victory: Eliminate the other player by taking over all of their nodes using explosions.
  • Path Victory: Be the first to move your UFO from the starting planet to the destination planet. Move the UFO by fully coloring the current planet of the path.
  • Control Victory: Fully occupy the king planet with your color for as many turns in a row as indicated.

These new objectives gave players freedom to adapt their strategies, focusing on aggressive expansion, tactical movement, or strategic control, making each match more varied and engaging.

picture.alt: Screenshots of the second version of Node Wars showcasing multiple winning conditions

steps.content:
Following the gameplay improvements, we focused on intuitiveness and user experience. A series of quality-of-life updates were implemented to make the game easier to understand, smoother to play, and more visually engaging.

Key improvements included:

  • A tutorial system to help first-time players grasp the propagation mechanic and overall game flow.
  • A game mode selection menu allowing players to switch between different configurations and objectives.
  • Enhanced visuals and animations that provided better feedback on player actions, making outcomes clearer and the game more intuitive to read.

These improvements made Node Wars more polished, approachable, and enjoyable, particularly for new players discovering the game for the first time.

Include pictures of tutorial screens.

picture.alt: Screenshots of the Node Wars tutorial and interface updates

process.results:
The final version was once again tested with players and received highly positive feedback. Indeed, it was rated as the top project among those presented. Testers highlighted its elegant mechanics, satisfying chain reactions, and strong sense of progression.

Future development opportunities include expanding the game with online multiplayer, as the current version supports only local play. Additional features could involve new maps and layouts to diversify strategies, more customization options for civilizations or visual themes, and further quality-of-life enhancements. A potential long-term goal is to adapt Node Wars for mobile platforms, making it accessible to a wider audience.
process.personal_reflection:
Making a video game was always a dream of mine, and doing so was a very enriching experience. Through this project, I learned some fundamental aspects of game design. For example the MDA framework and how to predict how game mechanics, which is the aspect of the game the developer can most easily modify, impacts the player experience.

Another fundamental concept I learned through this project is one definition of what a game is. Games, whatever the type they are, follow three basic rules:

  • They must have doable tasks. This doesn't mean that the game cannot be hard or complex — only that, at the end of the day, the game and its tasks should be possible to complete. For instance, running a marathon is hard for a random person, but it is doable even if it might take longer.
  • The game must offer understandable feedback. The player should be able to interpret how well they are performing to have a better experience. In the marathon example, having other runners provide you relative feedback on your performance ("are you better than others?" since it’s a race) and distance markers showing your progress ("how much farther do you have to run?") are both examples of meaningful feedback.
  • The game needs to take place in a safe environment. Otherwise, it shouldn't be considered a game. This principle means that games are defined by a kind of “magic” space where players can take risks, compete, or experience failure without suffering real-world consequences. Inside this boundary, players agree to follow a specific set of rules and to suspend certain real-world concerns for the sake of play.
